citation.title: Linhagens medievais portuguesas : genealogias e estratégias 1279-1325

wikipedia.title: Fernando, Lord of Serpa
wikipedia.summary: Infante Fernando of Portugal, or Ferdinand in English, was a Portuguese infante (prince), son of King Afonso II of Portugal and his wife Urraca of Castile, daughter of Alfonso VIII of Castile.

wikipedia.title: João Afonso Telo, 1st Count of Barcelos
wikipedia.summary: He was named the first Count of Barcelos on 8 May 1298 by King Denis who in 1302 appointed him ambassador to Castile.

wikipedia.title: Lopo Fernandes Pacheco
wikipedia.summary: He appears in 1317 with Infante Afonso and in 1318 was one of the witnesses when Afonso made several donations to the Monastery of Saint Denis in Odivelas.

wikipedia.title: Afonso I of Portugal
wikipedia.summary: The Portuguese nobility disliked the alliance between Galicia and Portugal and rallied around the infant Afonso.

wikipedia.title: João Afonso Telo de Menezes
wikipedia.summary: João Afonso Telo de Menezes (died 1381) was a Portuguese nobleman, 1st Count of Ourém, 1st Count of Viana do Alentejo, 4th Count of Barcelos.

wikipedia.title: Guillén Pérez de Guzmán
wikipedia.summary: Guillén Pérez de Guzmán (ca. 1180–1233), a member of the House of Guzmán, one of the most aristocratic of the Kingdom of Castile, he was the maternal grandfather of Queen Beatrice of Castile, Queen Consort of Portugal as the wife of King Alfonso III.

wikipedia.title: Gil Vasques de Soverosa
wikipedia.summary: Gil Vázquez de Soverosa (died c. 1240) was a member of the nobility of the Kingdom of Portugal, of the Soverosa lineage which had its origins in Galicia.

wikipedia.title: Rodrigo Gutiérrez Girón
wikipedia.summary: Rodrigo governed several feudal estates, including Gatón de Campos, Monzón, Torremormojón, Montealegre, half of Carrión and Liébana, all of which, except the last one, were situated in Tierra de Campos.

wikipedia.title: João Afonso de Albuquerque
wikipedia.summary: João Afonso de Albuquerque, (ca. 1304–28 September 1354), Juan Alfonso de Alburquerque in Spanish and knicknamed "o do Ataúde", 6th Lord of Alburquerque, was a member of the highest ranks of the nobility of the Kingdom of Portugal, an astute poli

wikipedia.title: Afonso IV of Portugal
wikipedia.summary: Afonso IV (8 February 1291 – 28 May 1357), called the Brave, was King of Portugal and the Algarves from 1325 until his death.

wikipedia.title: Beatrice of Castile (1293–1359)
wikipedia.summary: On 13 September 1297, when Beatrice was only four years old, the bilateral agreement, known as the Treaty of Alcañices, was signed between Castile and Portugal, putting an end to the hostilities between both kingdoms and establishing the definitive borders

wikipedia.title: Sancha, Lady of Alenquer
wikipedia.summary: Sancha of Portugal (Coimbra, 1180 – Celas Monastery, 13 March 1229), was a Portuguese infanta, second daughter of King Sancho I of Portugal and Dulce of Aragon.

wikipedia.title: Nuno Alvites
wikipedia.summary: Nuno Alvites, also referred to as Nuno or Nuño Aloitiz (fl. 1017–1028), was a count of Portugal, a descendant of the first count, Vímara Peres as the son of Count Alvito Nunes and Gontina.

wikipedia.title: Sancho I of Portugal
wikipedia.summary: Sancho I, nicknamed "the Populator", King of Portugal (11 November 1154 – 26 March 1212) was the second but only surviving legitimate son and fourth child of Afonso I of Portugal by his wife, Maud of Savoy.

wikipedia.title: Afonso II of Portugal
wikipedia.summary: Afonso II (English: Alphonzo), or Affonso (Archaic Portuguese), Alfonso or Alphonso (Portuguese-Galician) or Alphonsus (Latin version), nicknamed "the Fat" (Portuguese o Gordo), King of Portugal, was born in Coimbra on 23 April 1185 and died on 25 March 12

wikipedia.title: Leonor Teles
wikipedia.summary: Leonor Teles (or Teles de Meneses), was by marriage Queen consort of Portugal and one of the protagonists, along with her brothers and her daughter Beatrice, of the events that led to the Crisis of 1383–1385 that culminated in the defeat of her son-in-law,

wikipedia.title: Afonso Sanches, Lord of Albuquerque
wikipedia.summary: Afonso Sanches, Lord of Albuquerque (1289-1329; also known as Alfonso Sanches) was a Medieval nobleman, Lord of Cerva and Alburquerque.
